rename.from: Connection fails when host key is ecdsa-sha2-nistp384 or ecdsa-sha2-nistp512
rename.to: Connection fails when host key is ecdsa-sha2-nistp384 or ecdsa-sha2-nistp521

body: Could swear someone else already submitted this but I can't find it. Thanks!
Any chance this could get some merge-love? I've had to start patching my own installs for this bug :-(
I've been letting releases slip lately but almost done with the side project that's taken up my time, so I will be trying to give Paramiko a lot of love soon. Sorry for the delays!

issue.title: only rsa host key checked

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
I'm testing with Fabric==1.13.1, paramiko==2.1.1, cryptography==1.7.1

The default ssh server setup on ubuntu 16.04 (and probably most recent versions of ubuntu and debian) is to generate one of each kind of host key. The default `sshd_config` contains this:

```
Protocol 2
# HostKeys for protocol version 2
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_dsa_key
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ecdsa_key
HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key
```

When using the openssh client (6.9p1 on MacOS 10.11), it chooses the ecdsa key to put in `known_hosts`, and on later invocations it checks all the host keys the server presents to find the one of the appropriate type to check.

But paramiko seems to only look at the rsa one, sees that it's not the same type as what's in known_hosts, and so ignores it. Thus paramiko never notices when the host key changes.

```
$ ssh testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net
...
@    WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED!     @
...
Someone could be eavesdropping on you right now (man-in-the-middle attack)!
It is also possible that a host key has just been changed.
The fingerprint for the ECDSA key sent by the remote host is
SHA256:aB6l8o7WhWdJ02tPavyPBGTFgqe1VaqwuLVfJttiQ/c.
...
Offending ECDSA key in /Users/pierce/.ssh/known_hosts:19
ECDSA host key for testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net has changed and you have requested strict checking.
Host key verification failed.
$ fab -H testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net basictask
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] Executing task 'basictask'
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] run: hostname && echo hi there
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] out: testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] out: hi there
...
Disconnecting from testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net... done.
```

But if I put an incorrect rsa key in known_hosts, paramiko correctly notices that the host key is wrong. Or, if I put an incorrect ecdsa key in known_hosts, and change `sshd_config` to only offer the ecdsa key, paramiko correctly notices that the host key is wrong.

```
$ fab -H testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net basictask
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] Executing task 'basictask'
[testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net] run: hostname && echo hi there

Fatal error: Host key for testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net did not match pre-existing key! Server's key was changed recently, or possible man-in-the-middle attack.

Underlying exception:
    ('testdeploy03.ec2.st-av.net', <paramiko.ecdsakey.ECDSAKey object at 0x10c805310>, <paramiko.ecdsakey.ECDSAKey object at 0x10c7fb7d0>)

Aborting.
```

This also works to hide the problem pointed out in #794 - if the ecdsa-sha2-nistp384/521 key is not the only host key, if there is also a dsa or rsa host key in sshd_config, then paramiko will use the rsa or dsa host key and will seem to work. (But if you had the ecdsa key in known_hosts, it's not being checked.)

(As a final detail, recent openssh server and client will refuse to actually use the dsa key, I think it's obsolete.)

issue.title: Client unable to handle ecdsa-sha2-nistp256 based hosts

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
I'm currently using Paramiko to connect to my local SSH server, I'm running into issues however when the server in my known hosts file is using `ecdsa-sha2-nistp256`. Is there any way of adding support for this?

I'm currently using version *2.1.1* on *Python 3.6.0*

This is the code I'm using:
```
self.client = SSHClient()
self.client.load_system_host_keys()
self.client.connect(
    hostname=self.config.server_address,
    port=self.config.server_port,
    username=self.config.auth_username,
    pkey=self.config.auth_public_key )
```

issue.title: client: prefer keytype from known_hosts, more ecdsa server hostkey support

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
fixes #865 

Note that `Transport.connect()` already does something similar: if a hostkey is passed, it sets `_preferred_keys` to the type of that hostkey. (But SSHClient does not use Transport.connect(), it uses the alternative `start_client()` for more control.)

See commit messages for more details. Also, I'll be doing a bit more testing with different sets of key types available on the server, just to be sure...

issue.title: auth_handler rejects 384-bit and 521-bit ECDSA key

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
I get the following error when publickey auth with 384-bit ECDSA key to paramiko server. However, 256-bit ECDSA key works fine.

```
2017-02-22 02:34:24,877 [12915] INFO: Auth rejected (none).
2017-02-22 02:34:24,884 [12915] INFO: Auth rejected: unsupported or mangled public key
```

It seems `Transport._key_info` has only `ecdsa-sha2-nistp256`.
```diff
diff --git a/paramiko/transport.py b/paramiko/transport.py
index c4f0ca7c6..bfd22b637 100644
--- a/paramiko/transport.py
+++ b/paramiko/transport.py
@@ -207,8 +207,9 @@ class Transport (threading.Thread, ClosingContextManager):
     _key_info = {
         'ssh-rsa': RSAKey,
         'ssh-dss': DSSKey,
-        'ecdsa-sha2-nistp256': ECDSAKey,
     }
+    _key_info.update(map(lambda id_: (id_, ECDSAKey),
+                         ECDSAKey.supported_key_format_identifiers()))

     _kex_info = {
         'diffie-hellman-group1-sha1': KexGroup1,
```
After the patch, it works well.

And, it's difficult to investigate because an exception isn't logged when the error occurs. I consider the exception should be logged.
```diff
diff --git a/paramiko/auth_handler.py b/paramiko/auth_handler.py
index cab27a884..6486935ae 100644
--- a/paramiko/auth_handler.py
+++ b/paramiko/auth_handler.py
@@ -416,8 +416,9 @@ class AuthHandler (object):
             except SSHException as e:
                 self.transport._log(INFO, 'Auth rejected: public key: %s' % str(e))
                 key = None
-            except:
-                self.transport._log(INFO, 'Auth rejected: unsupported or mangled public key')
+            except Exception as e:
+                self.transport._log(INFO, 'Auth rejected: unsupported or mangled public key (%s: %s)',
+                                    e.__class__.__name__, e)
                 key = None
             if key is None:
                 self._disconnect_no_more_auth()
```
After this, I investigated the issue by the following log.
```
2017-02-22 02:43:00,367 [12253] INFO: Auth rejected: unsupported or mangled public key (KeyError: u'ecdsa
-sha2-nistp384')
```

issue.title: prefer ecdsa host key types

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
fixes #794 and #900 

second part of an alternative set of PRs to #899

issue.title: Problem connection to Arista node when using ansible 2.3.2 and paramiko 1.16.0-1 (the official Ubuntu 16.04.3 deb)

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a bug.

repository.name: ansible
repository.description: Ansible is a radically simple IT automation platform that makes your applications and systems easier to deploy and maintain. Automate everything from code deployment to network configuration to cloud management, in a language that approaches plain English, using SSH, with no agents to install on remote systems. https://docs.ansible.com.

issue.body:
<!---
Verify first that your issue/request is not already reported on GitHub.
Also test if the latest release, and master branch are affected too.
-->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Bug Report
 
##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Name of the module/plugin/task/feature -->
modules eos_*, paramiko 

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from ansible --version between quotes below -->
```
ansible 2.3.2.0
  config file = /home/ansible-manager/config/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
  python version = 2.7.12 (default, Nov 19 2016, 06:48:10) [GCC 5.4.0 20160609]
```

##### CONFIGURATION
<!---
Mention any settings you have changed/added/removed in ansible.cfg
(or using the ANSIBLE_* environment variables).
-->
Default configuration

##### OS / ENVIRONMENT
<!---
Mention the OS you are running Ansible from, and the OS you are
managing, or say N/A for anything that is not platform-specific.
Also mention the specific version of what you are trying to control,
e.g. if this is a network bug the version of firmware on the network device.
-->

- Answible running from Ubuntu 
```
lsb_release -a
```
> Distributor ID: Ubuntu
> Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
> Release:        16.04
> Codename:       xenial

```
dpkg -s ansible
```

> Package: ansible
> Status: install ok installed
> Priority: optional
> Section: admin
> Installed-Size: 15830
> Maintainer: Ansible, Inc. <info@ansible.com>
> Architecture: all
> Version: 2.3.2.0-1ppa\~xenial
> Depends: python-jinja2, python-yaml, python-paramiko, python-httplib2, python-six, python-crypto (>= 2.6), python-setuptools, sshpass, python-pkg-resources, python:any (<< 2.8), python:any (>= 2.7.5-5~)

```
dpkg -s python-paramiko
```
> Package: python-paramiko
> Status: install ok installed
> Priority: optional
> Section: python
> Installed-Size: 619
> Maintainer: Ubuntu Developers <ubuntu-devel-discuss@lists.ubuntu.com>
> Architecture: all
> Source: paramiko
> Version: 1.16.0-1
> Provides: python2.7-paramiko
> Depends: python-crypto (>= 2.1.0-2), python-ecdsa, python:any (<< 2.8), python:any (>= 2.7.5-5~)


- trying to control Arista (Virtual) switch 

```
show version
```
> Arista vEOS
> Software image version: 4.18.1F
> Architecture:           i386
> Internal build version: 4.18.1F-4591672.4181F
> Internal build ID:      6fcb426e-70a9-48b8-8958-54bb72ee28ed
> 

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Explain the problem briefly -->
This is not really ansible bug, but rather the official ubuntu paramiko package for 16.04.3  has some limitations. In short Paramiko 1.16.0-1 does not work with *ecdsa-sha2-nistp521* keys from *.ssh/known_hosts*. There is an [already fixed bug](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/794) about that in paramiko. Arista switches have such type of key and it will be offered to ssh first.

When ssh adds automatically the node(Arista) ssh key to *.ssh/known_hosts* after simple logging into the Arista switch from bash
```bash
ssh administrator@test-arista-sw
```
> The authenticity of host 'test-arista-sw (192.168.100.128)' can't be established.
> ECDSA key fingerprint is SHA256:2CCjPqusOQ7wL8AvVXdM3968AClEQucxBXhVBTz1XH8.
> Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
> Warning: Permanently added '192.168.100.128' (ECDSA) to the list of known hosts.
 
an *ecdsa-sha2-nistp521* host key is offered from the arista switch and added. Assuming we have already valid key for the host ansible should connect without problems. But
```
export ANSIBLE_LOG_PATH=~/ansible.log
export ANSIBLE_DEBUG=True
ansible-playbook -vvvv get_arista_facts.yml
```
fails with 
> unable to open shell. Please see: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/network_debug_troubleshooting.html#unable-to-open-shell

and in the ansible.log

> paramiko.hostkeys Unable to handle key of type ecdsa-sha2-nistp521
> paramiko.transport starting thread (client mode): 0x7327f650L
> paramiko.transport Local version/idstring: SSH-2.0-paramiko_1.16.0
> paramiko.transport Remote version/idstring: SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_6.6.1
> paramiko.transport Connected (version 2.0, client OpenSSH_6.6.1)
> paramiko.transport kex algos:[u'curve25519-sha256@libssh.org', u'ecdh-sha2-nistp521', u'ecdh-sha2-nistp256', u'ecdh-sha2-nistp384', u'diffie-hellman-group14-sha1'] server key:[u'ssh-rsa', u'ecdsa-sha2-nistp521', u'ssh-ed25519'] client encrypt:[u'aes256-gcm@openssh.com', u'aes128-gcm@openssh.com', u'aes256-ctr', u'aes192-ctr', u'aes128-ctr'] server encrypt:[u'aes256-gcm@openssh.com', u'aes128-gcm@openssh.com', u'aes256-ctr', u'aes192-ctr', u'aes128-ctr'] client mac:[u'hmac-sha2-512-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha2-256-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha1-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha2-512', u'hmac-sha2-256',u'hmac-sha1'] server mac:[u'hmac-sha2-512-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha2-256-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha1-etm@openssh.com', u'hmac-sha2-512', u'hmac-sha2-256', u'hmac-sha1'] client compress:[u'none', u'zlib@openssh.com'] server compress:[u'none', u'zlib@openssh.com'] client lang:[u''] server lang:[u''] kex follows?False
> paramiko.transport Kex agreed: diffie-hellman-group14-sha1
> paramiko.transport Cipher agreed: aes128-ctr
> paramiko.transport MAC agreed: hmac-sha2-256
> paramiko.transport Compression agreed: none
> paramiko.transport kex engine KexGroup14 specified hash_algo <built-in function openssl_sha1>
> /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/Crypto/Cipher/blockalgo.py:141: FutureWarning: CTR mode needs counter parameter, not IV 
> self._cipher = factory.new(key, *args, **kwargs)
> paramiko.transport Switch to new keys ...
> p=6763 u=ansible-manager |  connecting to host 192.168.100.128 returned an error
> p=6763 u=ansible-manager |  (14, 'Bad address')
> paramiko.transport EOF in transport thread
> p=6763 u=ansible-manager |  number of connection attempts exceeded, unable to connect to control socket
> p=6763 u=ansible-manager |  persistent_connect_interval=1, persistent_connect_retries=30
> p=6713 u=ansible-manager |  open_shell() returned 255   6763 1502874086.82866: Loading Connection 'ssh' from /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py (found_in_cache=False, class_only=True)
>  failed to connect to control socket

Adding *ANSIBLE_PARAMIKO_HOST_KEY_AUTO_ADD=True* will override the key with the provided ssh-rsa.

Again - there is an [already fixed bug](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/issues/794) about that in paramiko. This bug report is just to save someone time as there are simple workarounds.

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!---
For bugs, show exactly how to reproduce the problem, using a minimal test-case.
For new features, show how the feature would be used.
-->
On clean Ubuntu installation run
```bash
apt-add-repository -y ppa:ansible/ansible
apt-get update
apt-get install ansible
```

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
```yaml
---
- name: Get facts on the Arista switch
  hosts: test-arista-sw
  connection: local

 tasks:
  - name: Get facts
    eos_facts:
      gather_subset: all
      provider: "{{ ans_provider }}"

  vars:
    ans_provider:
      host: "{{ inventory_hostname }}"
      username: administrator
      password: testtest
      authorize: yes
      transport: cli
      port: 22
```

<!--- You can also paste gist.github.com links for larger files -->

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
<!--- What did you expect to happen when running the steps above? -->
Receive the facts object provided by the eos_facts module.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
<!--- What actually happened? If possible run with extra verbosity (-vvvv) -->
> MSG: unable to open shell. Please see: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/network_debug_troubleshooting.html#unable-to-open-shell

<!--- Paste verbatim command output between quotes below -->
```

```
##### Workarounds
One can do one of the:
- Remove manually the *ecdsa-sha2-nistp521* key from ~/.ssh/known_hosts and add ssh-rsa instead
- add *ANSIBLE_PARAMIKO_HOST_KEY_AUTO_ADD=True* which will override ~/.ssh/known_hosts and replace the *ecdsa-sha2-nistp521* with the *ssh-rsa*  provided by the arista switch.
- Update *python-paramiko* deb with py2deb or stdeb with version that includes the fixed bug.

body: Glad to see this is supported. Looks like the docs need updating though. (Grep for "keytype" in <http://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.4/api/hostkeys.html>.)
